title: We often hear of the Roman Empire collapsing which makes it sound like an overnight affair, but what did it mean to the average Roman (especially in the West)? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well since there was no such thing as “your average Roman” it meant certainly “an end.” Since Latin would be continued to be used well into Western European Middle Ages as a way of evading restrictions on the spread of novel ideas “Romanism” in the form of the Latin Language in fact thrived in the West and I think one could argue was a major factor in how the relatively obscure “Western Empire” whilst shattered politically by the Fall of Rome would one day come to dominate the entire World.

At the time the central authority of the Western Roman Empire collapsed, security was provided by local militias and bucellari of rich people. The empire was an overhead for which taxes with diminishing returns were paid. Throughout the Middle Ages there are strong resentments against possible reunifications in the realm of the former Western Roman Empire. So I guess a lot of people were happy that it was finally gone and replaced by a much weaker central entity in the form of the Papacy and the Catholic church.
